chapter.title: Virtual Machines
chapter.para: The VM specific elements which may be contained in the virtual machine description are as follows:

chapter.para: When creating a new VM, the name, template and cluster elements are required. The template and cluster may be identified by id or name. The name, description, type, memory, cpu topology, os and stateless properties may be updated post-creation.
There are a number of possible actions for VMs - start, stop, shutdown, suspend, detach, migrate, export, import and ticket.

section.title: Devices
section.para: A VM's devices are represented and managed through a number of collections which behave similarly to other collections, as described by .
There are four device collections available for each VM - cdroms, disks and nics. The URI for each of these collections are available via link elements in the VM representation.

section.title: CD-ROM Devices
section.para:
CD-ROM devices are represented by a cdrom element containing the following properties:
file id A reference to an ISO image. See
When adding a new CD-ROM, the file id property is required.

note.para: Note that a VM may currently only have a single CD-ROM and it is not possible to modify the CD-ROM properties using PUT.

section.title: Disk Devices
section.para: Disk devices are represented by a disk element containing the following properties:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: Size of the disk in bytes
One of DATA, SHARED, SWAP, SYSTEM or TEMP
The type (function) of the disk device
One of ILLEGAL, INVALID, LOCKED or OK
The status of the disk device
One of IDE, SCSI or VIRTIO
The type of interface driver used to connect to the disk device
The underlying storage format. Copy On Write (COW) allows snapshots, with a small performance overhead. Raw does not allow snapshots, but offers improved performance.
true if the physical storage for the disk should not be preallocated
true if this disk is to be marked as bootable
true if the underlying physical storage for the disk should be zeroed when the disk is deleted
true if disk errors should not cause VM to be paused and, instead, disk errors should be propagated to the guest OS
The ID of the associated storage domain, only used when adding the first disk to a VM that was not itself created from a template

footnote.para: Only required when the first disk is being added to a VM that was not itself created from a template.

section.para: When adding a new disk, the size property is required. Also the storage_domain ID is needed in the case of the first disk being added to a VM that was not itself created from a template.

note.para: Note that it is not possible to modify disk properties using PUT.

section.title: Network Interface Devices
section.para: Network interface devices are represented by a nic element containing the following properties:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: The name of the guest network device, e.g. eth0
A reference to the network which the interface should be connected
One of E1000, PV, RTL8139 or RTL8139_PV
The type of driver used for the nic
The MAC address of the interface
IP level details on the interface configuration, obtained from a guest agent if available

section.para: When adding a new network interface, the name and network id properties are required.

note.para: Note that it is not possible to modify network interface properties using PUT.

section.title: Snapshots
section.para: A VM may have any number of snapshots of its disk state and these are represented and managed through a collection which behaves similarly to other collections, as described by .
VM snapshots are represented by a snapshot element containing the following snapshot-specific properties:

note.title: Element property icons
note.para: The icons used in the properties column of this table are described in

row.entry: The ID and URI of the VM to which this snapshot pertains
The date and time at which this snapshot was created.
A link to the previous snapshot of this VM

section.para: When adding a new snapshot, only the description property may be specified.

note.para: Note that it is not possible to modify snapshot properties using PUT.

section.para: A VM may be restored to a given snapshot using the rel="restore" action link in the snapshot description e.g.

section.title: Users
section.para: A desktop VM may have a set of users attached to it, represented via the users sub-collection. As per the usual idiom, POSTing to this collection attaches a user to the VM, whereas DELETEing from it has the effect of detaching that user.

note.para: Users referenced in this way must already exist in the Red Hat Enterprise Virtualization Manager user database, and may be identified either via their ID or by user prinicpal name (see ). In the example below, the latter approach is taken.

section.screen: POST /rhevm-api/vms/5114bb3e-a4e6-44b2-b783-b3eea7d84720/users HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml Accept: application/xml <user> <user_name>rhevmadmin@domain.example.com</user_name> </user>

section.title: Start Action
section.para: Launch a VM.

The start action allows a vm element to be provided as a parameter. If a vm element is provided, boot-specific properties of the VM will be overridden at start time, using the values from the provided element. The properties will only be overriden for this boot of the VM, and will not be persisted for the next boot.
section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/vms/0/start HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <pause>true</pause> <vm> <host id="02447ac6-bcba-448d-ba2b-f0f453544ed2"/> <stateless>true</stateless> <display> <type>SPICE</type> </display> <os> <boot dev="cdrom"/> </os> <cdroms> <cdrom> <file id="foo.iso"/> </cdrom> </cdroms> <floppies> <floppy> <file id="bar.vfd"/> </floppy> </floppies> </vm> </action>

section.title: Stop Action
section.para: Forcibly power-off a VM.

section.title: Shutdown Action
section.para: Request that a VM shuts down.

section.title: Suspend Action
section.para: Save the VM state to disk and stop it. The VM state can later be restored using the start action.

section.title: Detach Action
section.para: Detach a VM from a VM pool.

section.title: Migrate Action
section.para: Migrate a VM to another physical host. The destination host id or name is a required parameter.

section.title: Export Action
section.para: Export a VM to an Export storage domain. A destination storage domain must be specified with a storage_domain reference. By default, the export action will overwrite any existing VM by the same name in the destination domain, but this may be avoided by setting the exclusive parameter to true. Finally, if snapshots of the VM should not be included in the exported VM, the discard_snapshots parameter may be set to true.

section.title: Import Action
section.para: Import a VM from an Export storage domain. The destination cluster and storage domain must be specified via cluster and storage_domain references.

note.para: The import action is only available on VMs listed under an Export storage domain. See .

section.screen:
POST /rhevm-api/datacenters/d70d5e2d-b8ad-494a-a4d2-c7a5631073c4/storagedomains/fabe0451-701f-4235-8f7e-e20e458819ed/vms/082c794b-771f-452f-83c9-b2b5a19c0399/import HTTP/1.1 Content-type: application/xml
<action> <storage_domain name="images0"/> <cluster name="Default"/> </action>

section.title: Ticket Action
section.para: Generate a time-sensitive authentication token for accessing this VM's display. The client-provided action may optionally include a ticket representation containing a value (if the token string needs to take on a particular form), and/or an expiry time in minutes. In any case, the completion response will specify the actual ticket value and expiry used.
